text: I think that depends who your are <@U01B8031PM1>, from your perspective coming at this with a high skill set and reasons to be confident you could be right, but absent that...... not so much. Also I imagine you were earning well before you started this which puts you in a different position to most people. For the man in the street an extra £10k a year makes a much bigger difference than £100k might to you or me. I think for that guy keeping it modest and low risk would be the right attitude. It's easy to lose perspective on money once you get used to it.

text:
Totally get it. Sorry did not mean to come across as arrogant there. There are hobbyists amongst us and they should for sure expend resources and time and aim for whatever money + enjoyment + skill set uplift they can get.

For full time pro gamblers, which I believe <@U01DCR5PXDY> is, who could also get a high paying tech job at the drop of a hat, those kinds of people should absolutely be playing for big time. Otherwise the opportunity cost is too high.

text:
I have a strategy where I would like to lay at BSP.

I want to size each bet so that my prospective win amount is 1 unit. In other words, for each bet the backer's stake will be 1 unit.

My understanding is that for a Market On Close order, I can only specify the liability not the backer's stake. This makes sense as you don't know what price you will get filled at.

From discussions with <@U4H19D1D2>, I've realised it is possible to place a Limit On Close order which would let me cap the maximum BSP I would lay at (with the bet being cancelled if BSP is above this price). I am thinking that I can use this to achieve my goal as follows:

1. Look to execute bets a small number of seconds before the market start time, e.g. 10 seconds before
2. Roughly predict what the BSP would be. I am thinking to use the near SP field
3. Take the near SP and add a few ticks to allow for some movement. This will be the `limit_price`
4. Work out `liability` as `unit_size * (limit_price - 1)`
5. Place a Limit On Close order at `limit_price` with liability `liability`

Thoughts? Anyone already doing something similar?

4. Work out

as

5. Place a Limit On Close order at

with liability

Thoughts? Anyone already doing something similar?

text: Oh I see - I thought you wanted to trade in the lit market before placing some BSP orders. Sounds reasonable TBH. Some events do start quite a few minutes after the official start time so if ur concern is placing right before the uncrossing you may need a more reliable indicator of when the race will start.

elements.text: Oh I see - I thought you wanted to trade in the lit market before placing some BSP orders. Sounds reasonable TBH. text: So the idea is that I don’t know what the true price is for these horses but I do know that over a large enough sample laying at BSP will be value. So the goal is to lay at BSP or better. A separate but obvious concern is to not affect (too much) what the BSP will be. Not sure whether what you propose would be more successful at these goals or not

elements.text: So the idea is that I don’t know what the true price is for these horses but I do know that over a large enough sample laying at BSP will be value. So the goal is to lay at BSP or better. A separate but obvious concern is to not affect (too much) what the BSP will be. Not sure whether what you propose would be more successful at these goals or not

text: I have also seen people chop up their BSP orders into smaller chunks, each chunk placed a tick away from the previous. Presumably this is to stop leaking alpha to someone who is looking for very large volumes at a single price. Not sure how useful this is in terms of reducing market impact, but maybe a useful execution style in this regard :shrug: never tried it myself.

elements.text: I have also seen people chop up their BSP orders into smaller chunks, each chunk placed a tick away from the previous. Presumably this is to stop leaking alpha to someone who is looking for very large volumes at a single price. Not sure how useful this is in terms of reducing market impact, but maybe a useful execution style in this regard
never tried it myself.

text: They only way that I can see that chopping up BSP orders into smaller chunks would affect the BSP would be if indeed it didn't alert others who would otherwise have followed you in impacting the auction. All the chunks are going to be aggregated in the auction so it lots of little still equals one big when the price is determined.

elements.text: They only way that I can see that chopping up BSP orders into smaller chunks would affect the BSP would be if indeed it didn't alert others who would otherwise have followed you in impacting the auction. All the chunks are going to be aggregated in the auction so it lots of little still equals one big when the price is determined.

text: <@UBS7QANF3> For dogs I've not found near price to be a particularly good indicator of the forthcoming BSP. However, it might be better in the deeper horses markets.

elements.text: For dogs I've not found near price to be a particularly good indicator of the forthcoming BSP. However, it might be better in the deeper horses markets.

text: <@U9JHLMZB4> - yes that's what I said, a single large order at one price point might signal something to someone who is looking for it (and otherwise not signal if that order was chopped up). Sure it's aggregated during uncrossing but while reconciliation hasn't occured, all BSP orders are fully visible in the API at each price point. To the unsophisticated participant, one might see many small orders and not recognize that they all came from one account.

elements.text: - yes that's what I said, a single large order at one price point might signal something to someone who is looking for it (and otherwise not signal if that order was chopped up). text: How accurate have people found backtesting to be in general? Ie if you were to compare back test results with actual over the same period. Would they be indicative or fairly accurate? Thanks

elements.text: How accurate have people found backtesting to be in general? Ie if you were to compare back test results with actual over the same period. Would they be indicative or fairly accurate? Thanks

text: I backtested a strategy on IP AUS racing using flumine. It had a reasonable number of bets and based on 12 months of back testing the expected ROI was 6%, now after roughly 6 months of real betting the ROI is at 4% so I would say it’s reasonably accurate but you may want a buffer in case.

elements.text: I backtested a strategy on IP AUS racing using flumine. It had a reasonable number of bets and based on 12 months of back testing the expected ROI was 6%, now after roughly 6 months of real betting the ROI is at 4% so I would say it’s reasonably accurate but you may want a buffer in case.

text: I have not back tested the same “live” period but that would be an interesting experiment

elements.text: I have not back tested the same “live” period but that would be an interesting experiment

text: <@U024TE5NPN1> has joined the channel

<@UQL0QDEKA>  very dependant on what you are doing, for example flumine has a few limitations in terms of doubling matching liquidity and delays etc. Inplay/volatility certainly makes things worse. As long as you factor this in and don’t go mad with stakes I actually find things to be better when live (inplay horse racing)
